data.title: Verizon's Earnings Beat Proves The 7% Yield Is Sustainable (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Yesterday, Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) released its third quarter earnings. The release beat analyst estimates on earnings per share (EPS) while narrowly missing on revenue. Earnings increased 50% on a reported basis and 1.6% on an adjusted basis. Adjusted EPS was 1.6% ahead of estimates.

Heading into Verizon’s third quarter earnings release, analysts had fairly low expectations for the company. The expected EPS result was for 0% change on a year-over-year basis, and revenue was expected to grow just 2%. Although revenue disappointed relative to even that pretty low bar, the overall results showed an improving margin on just slightly growing sales.

The results reported for the third quarter indicate that Verizon is becoming more profitable over time, and indeed, that is the long-term trend as well. In the table below, you can see that since year-end 2021, VZ’s gross profit has increased from $77.3 billion to $81.49 billion, while its revenue has increased from $133.6 billion to $137 billion. This indicates that the company’s gross profit margin has increased from 57.8% to 59.4%—a non-negligible increase.

So, we have a considerable increase in Verizon’s gross profit, as well as its gross profit margin, yet VZ stock is actually down 30% over a five-year period. It seems like there could be an opportunity here.

The fact that there's a potential opportunity in Verizon stock can be confirmed by looking at the stock’s value rating. According to Seeking Alpha Quant, VZ trades at a mere 8.3 times earnings, contributing to an A- valuation rating. This combined with increasing revenue and gross margins would appear to indicate cheapness.

Now, none of the above means anything if Verizon is destined to have its financial fortunes crumble tomorrow. We always need to attempt to gauge a company’s forward prospects before saying that it is truly cheap. I’ll explore that matter in detail in a later section. For now, I will simply point to the fact that the company has $383 billion in assets–only 5.9% of which are goodwill–and $3.6 billion in cash and marketable securities. This is a treasure chest the company can draw on to outlast competitors in times of stress and which can be used to make new investments. These simple facts bode well for Verizon’s future prospects–though obviously we need to look at much more than just balance sheet health before we can fully render a verdict on the matter.

Another thing investors will want to know about Verizon stock following its third quarter release is its suitability as a dividend stock. Before VZ’s earnings came out, the company had a healthy payout ratio, with Seeking Alpha Quant confirming it at 57.6% for the trailing 12-month period. With VZ having posted positive earnings growth in the third quarter, that ratio is presumably coming down over time. So, VZ’s 7%-yielding dividend is getting better covered by earnings.

When I last covered Verizon stock, I rated it a Buy because of the improvements I saw in its operations. Since then, the company has grown and increased its profitability, while its stock has decreased in price. The underlying value would appear to be greater now. So, I am increasing my rating to Strong Buy.

Earnings Recap

Verizon’s recent earnings release mostly exceeded analyst expectations, boasting the following metrics:

  • $33.8 billion in revenue, up 1.6% year over year (miss by $400 million).

  • $1.17 in reported EPS, up 50%.

  • $1.21 in adjusted EPS, up 1.6% (beat by $0.02).

  • $28 billion in nine-month operating cash flow, up 5.6%.

  • $15.8 billion in nine-month free cash flow (FCF), up 8.9%.

  • $12.8 billion in adjusted EBITDA, up 2.4%.

  • $21 billion in wireless service revenue, up 2.1%.

  • $5.6 billion in wireless equipment revenue, up 5.2%.

  • 261,000 wireless net additions.

  • 306,000 broadband net additions.

  • Guidance for 1% to 3% EPS growth.

  • Guidance for $19.5 billion to $20.5 billion in full-year FCF.

Overall, the headline metrics were all pretty satisfactory. Additionally, there were some nice tidbits of information away in the release as well, for example:

  • There were 61,000 internet net additions in the quarter, the best result seen in two years.

  • Postpaid average revenue per account (ARPA) improved 2%.

  • The company had 13.2 million total broadband customers by the end of the quarter.

  • It also delivered a $6.7 billion reduction in net debt.

These additional facts go to show that Verizon is not only beating earnings expectations but also improving its financial condition as well as customer totals. It looks like a pretty good picture.

Future Prospects

Having looked at VZ’s most recent periodic performance, we can now attempt to gauge its future prospects. I already touched on this in the introduction, when I wrote that the company has a lot of assets and cash with which to invest. That is one competitive edge that could drive future growth for VZ. Another, less measurable (but still important) edge the company has is a strong focus on premium plans. While telcos in general don’t enjoy much pricing power, with service prices declining long-term, there are segments of the telco market where suppliers have more power. One of those is the “ultra high speed” segment, where unlimited 5G plans can often come at a significant cost to consumers. Customers are often willing to pay up for such plans. This is particularly the case with customers who need constant high-speed internet, such as gamers and business owners. Verizon is investing heavily in servicing such consumers, buying up fibre optic companies to help serve them.

Valuation

Next up, we can look at the multiples that Verizon trades at. At today’s price, VZ is a pretty cheap-looking stock, trading at 8.3 times earnings, 1.2 times sales, and 1.56 times book. You can see more multiples in the image below, courtesy of Seeking Alpha Quant.

One multiple that looks very intriguing here is the PEG ratio, which indicates truly extreme cheapness after factoring in growth. I don’t think that VZ’s earnings growth rate is going to remain at 103% forever–the company doesn’t have the top-line growth to support that–but it should be positive. So, I expect VZ to continue having a respectable PEG ratio, unless its price rises dramatically.

As for what VZ is worth in terms of discounted cash flows:

I found from Capital IQ data that analysts estimate VZ’s cost of equity at 7% and its long-term earnings growth rate at 1.3%. Using these estimates as well as Seeking Alpha Quant’s estimate of VZ’s FCF per share, I got a $85.79 fair value estimate. See workings below:

Risks

Despite all the positive things I’ve written about VZ in this article, I do see the stock and its investors as facing certain risk factors. These include:

  1. Competition. There are many telcos in the United States, and some, such as AT&T Inc. (T) are quite strong and well funded. They could bring competition to Verizon that puts pressure on its margins.

  2. Little pricing power. Verizon does not appear to have much pricing power, as evidenced by the fact that it experienced subscriber loss when it attempted to hike prices earlier this year.

  3. High costs. Telco services are capital-intensive owing to the fact that they run on large amounts of heavy infrastructure. This typically requires them to borrow lots of money, although Verizon has been paying down its debt in recent quarters.

The above risks are worth keeping in mind. However, Verizon’s cheapness more than adequately compensates for them, making the company's stock a buy in my books.

data.title: Undercovered Dozen: Zoomd Technologies, Waste Management, DroneShield And More
data.description:
The Undercovered Dozen is a weekly Seeking Alpha editor-curated series highlighting 12 articles on lesser-covered stocks from the previous seven days. We hope this provides ideas and inspires discussion among the community.

Today, we're looking at articles published between Oct. 24 and Oct. 30.

Take a look at what these less-covered stocks might hold for you. And please join the conversation below to share what you think: Are any of these worth following up on? And are there other undercovered ideas that you like?

Zoomd Technologies: How A Microcap AdTech Player Is Winning The Open Internet Battle

Dmitri Vinokurov | Strong Buy

Zoomd Technologies Ltd. (OTCPK:ZMDTF, ZOMD:CA) is a small yet highly profitable advertising technology firm that is currently in hypergrowth. Despite this, the firm trades at extremely attractive valuations, both on a P/E and FCF growth basis, with the valuations being supported by strong execution of management and sector tailwinds.

Since executing a strategic repositioning in Q2 of 2023, the firm has been able to see growth as high as the high double digits Y/Y, and has turned from unprofitability to net income margins as high as 31%. As repositioning efforts commenced, the company has diversified further between clients and sectors, continued to expand into new, high-margin sectors, and reduced operating expenses through the use of AI and machine learning. On top of this, the firm currently holds no GAAP-accountable debt, strengthening the risk/reward of this investment.

These factors, combined with recent catalysts of bullish analyst coverage and partnerships that expand the reach of Zoomd, all strengthen my bullish thesis in the company.

As part of my analysis of Zoomd Technologies Ltd., I would like to initiate coverage with a "Strong Buy" rating.

Read more here...

Waste Management's Downturn Doesn't Justify It Sitting In The Waste Bin

Daniel Jones | Buy

As a value investor, I prioritize valuation above most other things when it comes to making an investment decision. But there are other factors to consider as well. As an example, I usually give additional wiggle room to high-quality companies with industry-leading positions. And if those businesses are growing at a nice pace, I give even more wiggle room. A great example of this that, recently, has fallen a bit short, is none other than the appropriately named Waste Management (WM). Since I reaffirmed the company as a ‘buy’ candidate in early March of this year, the S&P 500 has shot up 13%. But over that same time, shares of the company have dropped 6.6%. This is disheartening to say the least. But honestly, all this does, in my view, is open up a door for additional purchases for those who are inclined to do so.

The fact of the matter is that Waste Management has achieved strong growth recently. And in all likelihood, that growth will continue for the foreseeable future. In fact, for the upcoming earnings release covering the third quarter of the 2025 fiscal year, which management is supposed to announce on October 28th before the market opens, revenue and profits are both expected to rise. It is true that shares are not as cheap as I would like them to be. But compared to other major players in the market, the stock is certainly affordable. So unless some major negative event comes out of the woodwork, I will almost certainly maintain my ‘buy’ rating on the stock.

Read more here...

Pagaya Technologies: The AI Credit Platform Turning Data Into Durable Profits

Pau Galindo Ortigosa | Strong Buy

Pagaya Technologies (PGY) stock reached a new high of $44.99 on September 19, 2025. The new high comes after the stock rallied more than 400% from its 2025 lows of $9. Following such a huge jump, the market is now beginning to grasp the structural adjustments being undertaken at this AI-driven credit infrastructure company.

While investors focus on the volatility of fintech and legacy credit issues, a more important story might be the “Underwriting Flywheel,” a major shift toward a platform that uses data and partnerships to achieve better efficiency and steady growth in free cash flow over the next three to five years.

This isn’t merely a cyclical upswing in consumer credit. Pagaya is one of the most advanced AI underwriting networks in fintech, moving from breakeven to an enormously profitable credit infrastructure company. Indeed, Pagaya helps 31 lenders and over 145 institutional investors approve loans. The company has reached an important milestone trailing twelve months revenue as of Q2 2025 was $1.15 billion, with $487 million in gross profit (42% margin), EBITDA of $193 million, and operating income of $162 million, all growing at sustainably double digit rates. This durability is being severely discounted at current multiples of about 8x forward EV/EBITDA and about 2.3x forward EV/Sales. An intrinsic value of $39 for Pagaya stock says this analysis: it is a strong buy as re-rating materializes within twelve months.

Read more here...

IonQ And D-Wave Quantum Compared Amid Rumored Trump Administration Investments

APAC Investment News | Buy

Is the Trump Administration looking to invest directly in quantum computing? The Wall Street Journal certainly thinks so, and recently reported that insiders have claimed the United States may make equity investments. That said, a spokesperson for the Department of Commerce denied the claims. Ultimately, I suspect talks are indeed taking place, although currently they may be in so early a stage that it would be inappropriate to announce anything to the public just yet.

What I am confident about is that the Administration will offer strong support for quantum computing. The technology could prove crucial to national defense and the larger economy. In the long run, I believe Alphabet (GOOGL)(GOOG) is the best quantum company to invest in. IBM (IBM) and Microsoft (MSFT) are also appealing, especially in regard to their quantum efforts. That said, small quantum startups also offer interesting high-risk/high-reward investment opportunities worth investing risk capital in. Any major technological breakthroughs by these companies could send them to the moon.

Both IonQ, Inc. (IONQ) and D-Wave Quantum Inc. (QBTS) are good choices in my opinion, and because the companies take substantially different approaches to quantum technologies, investors can diversify their quantum investments to some extent.

Read more here...

Canadian Natural Resources: Competitive Leadership And New Sanctions Create Conditions For Growth

Dmytro Lebid | Buy

The recent news that has shaken the oil market opens up additional potential for strategic growth for companies involved in oil production in Canada. The Canadian Natural Resources Limited (CNQ) is the largest producer of Canadian oil, with high financial stability and potential for further scaling of export activities. With CNQ's per-barrel production costs significantly lower than those of its main industry competitors in North America, it has the guarantee of maintaining positive financial results during a downturn in the oil market.

Moreover, new sanctions against Russia's oil industry could potentially halt Russian oil supplies to China and India. If the capacity of the Trans Mountain pipeline is fully utilized, Canadian Natural Resources could increase its oil supplies by concluding new agreements with Chinese oil refineries. Moreover, for oil prices, the new sanctions against Russian oil companies are an additional factor that, if not raising the cost of hydrocarbons, then at least halting its decline in the short and medium term.

Considering CNQ's positive outlook and competitive advantages, I recommend these shares as a "Buy." In this article, I will reveal more detailed information about the reasons behind my decision. That said, I am not an active supporter of the bullish camp when it comes to oil companies. For instance, my latest fundamental analysis of the oil company Civitas Resources (CIVI) resulted in a "Sell" recommendation. I see a similar assessment for most participants in the North American oil market, due to the previously negative impact of fundamental factors.

Read more here...

PLTY: Close To Covered Call Perfection

Gary Bourgeault | Hold

YieldMax PLTR Option Income Strategy ETF (PLTY) is a covered call ETF primarily designed to generate income by incorporating a synthetic covered call strategy, meaning it doesn't own any of the underlying Palantir Technologies (PLTR) stock. It generates income from selling call options against the underlying.

The covered call strategy it uses caps much of the upside, but it also uses puts to mitigate some of the downside risk. That doesn't mean the share price of PLTY can't take off, because it has as I'll show you below. Even so, the chance of the ETF retaining large gains based upon the price surge of PLTR is very low.

Having said that, the reason I assert PLTY is close to covered call perfection, is it is operating exactly how a healthy covered call ETF should.

Read more here...

The AI Hype Could End Early For Power Solutions International

Alpha Mantra | Hold

The AI hype has turned the fortunes of many stocks in the last 2 years, making once-overlooked companies into hot stocks. One of the stocks riding this AI bandwagon has been Power Solutions International, Inc. (PSIX), which has surged 20-fold in a matter of ~two years. The meteoric rise of PSIX has been driven by its timely pivot toward catering to AI data center-related demand as opposed to its legacy business catering to the industrial and transportation sector.

I believe the demand related to data centers continues to be robust, with hyperscalers and other cloud providers either setting up or pledging to set up multi-gigawatt-scale data centers. While PSIX should benefit from this tailwind, I believe its unique position as a lesser-established player in the industry makes it vulnerable as the competitive industry brews up and customers switch back to more established players. Furthermore, a significant stake sale by an insider further makes me cautious about PSIX's prospects.

While my outlook is quite cautious on the stock, I am refraining from issuing a sell rating, particularly due to good fundamental momentum in the data center space. I would like to wait for a confirmation sign that competitive intensity is growing and materially affecting PSIX’s numbers, particularly margins. Until then, I would be sitting on the sidelines with a hold (neutral) rating on the stock.

Read more here...

NuScale: Danger Signs On Meltdown Of Speculative Froth

JR Research | Hold

I've never been that interested in investing in energy companies, let alone companies that specialize in nuclear energy technology like NuScale Power Corporation (SMR). However, 2025 has been a real eye-opener even to a seasoned investor and market watcher that I consider myself to be, as the stock of money-losing companies has continued its rampaging run. That said, I'm not particularly perturbed about missing "big speculative opportunities" if they aren't backed by solid fundamentals.

Also, I'm not especially keen on scooping up so-called "undervalued" plays in the fundamentally/structurally challenged sectors of the market (like the oil and gas peers, some healthcare plays, etc.). Investors who position the majority of their portfolios in these sectors have arguably missed out on partaking in the advance impelled by the tech and Mag 7 stocks as they demonstrate their AI prowess while also continuing to build their clout in this fourth industrial AI revolution.

I brought up the issue of speculative opportunities earlier because I believe SMR stock falls right into such a setup. It's not a coincidence that SMR is also the acronym for "small modular reactor" as much as it refers specifically to the ticker symbol for NuScale Power. What's critical for investors to note is that the company has consistently positioned itself as a key technology enabler or provider, encompassing its burgeoning partnership with ENTRA1, while also relying on Doosan as its key manufacturing partner. The reportedly asset-light approach is designed to help NuScale potentially avoid the CapEx complexities and financing challenges entailed with being a developer while also benefiting from the manufacturing expertise of a trusted supply chain partner.

Yet, the drawback suggests that it's imperative for NuScale to manage the supply chain dynamics extremely well in this early stage of the SMR buildout, even though it has obtained NRC approval. In addition, I believe we must also be cognizant of the challenges that encompass the multi-year rollout of NuScale's ability to scale, given the investments it has made in long-lead materials this year to pave the runway for a 2030 commercial operation date status, which is pivotal to justifying the extremely frothy valuation metrics that complement its investment thesis right now.

Read more here...

DroneShield: Potential For Exponential Revenue Growth

Stephen Tobin | Strong Buy

DroneShield (OTCPK:DRSHF) is an Australian company that manufactures counter-drone systems. With deployed solutions in 50 countries, it has become the market leader in this burgeoning industry. (I will use A$ to signify when I am writing about Australian dollar amounts.)

The sector has enormous growth potential, benefiting from industry tailwinds as countries gear up their defence against drones that have proven so effective and difficult to counter in recent conflicts.

I believe the company has a good chance of increasing its revenue from the reported A$58 million in 2024 to A$2.5 billion by 2030. That's a 4,200% increase and could catapult the company's share price from today's A$5 to over A$50.

DroneShield technology provides a sustainable competitive advantage, and it is gearing up its manufacturing operations to give it the capacity to hit the $2.5 billion sales target by the end of 2026 with new facilities expected to come online in Europe (Q1) and the US (Q3).

Read more here...

Deckers: Q2 Sell-Off Created A Buying Opportunity

Caffital Research | Buy

Deckers Outdoor Corporation (DECK) reported the company’s fiscal Q2 results from the July-September period on the 23rd of October. The footwear company continued to show strength in the two primary brands, HOKA and UGG, but a weaker-than-expected FY2026 sales guidance has sent the stock down -11% in pre-market action at the time of writing.

I cautiously remained at a Hold rating in my previous July article, titled “Deckers: An Attractive Entry Point Is Nearing”. The stock has since lost -14% of its value, continuing to underperform the S&P 500's 8% return. I believe that an attractive entry point is finally here, as the market has become overly concerned.

Read more here...

Canadian Natural: Undervalued Strength In A Volatile Oil Market

Louis Gerard | Strong Buy

It has been a couple of months since I last reviewed Canadian Natural Resources, and it has been a roller coaster of emotions for the Oil & Gas industry following the decline in crude prices. CNQ has shown a total return of 2.67% since, and I believe that with the company’s Q3 earnings incoming, CNQ should be closely followed by value investors.

As a reminder to readers, Canadian Natural Resources Limited (CNQ) (CNQ:CA) is one of the largest independent oil & gas producers, not only in Canada but in the world. It currently owns a diversified set of production with both oil sands and conventional and natural gas.

Read more here...

United Parcel Service: Back On Track, Cash Flow Supports Dividend

Ragmar Rikberg | Buy

With more and more headlines pointing to stock market overvaluation and at least some degree of correction seemingly around the corner, I believe this is the perfect time to turn some attention toward defensive stocks. They say it's wise to take a safe position while the music’s still playing and the lights are on. And even if the party lasts longer than expected, it's always smart to have some, maybe not the front-line growers, but great value stocks in your portfolio.

In my opinion, one area worth exploring for relatively safe plays is the category of so-called “fallen angels” — solid leaders with well-established businesses that are currently facing turbulence. However, if the issues seem to be rather temporary ones, the business model isn’t broken, the financials remain within a credible range, and competitive management is in place, then these companies could be well-positioned for recovery.

Easy to say, hard to find — at least in my experience. Still, I carved out some dedicated time and started digging and ended up with two companies I think are worth a closer look. One of them, which I started reviewing last week, had an earnings release just around the corner, offers an 11% dividend, runs a somewhat old-fashioned and sluggish — but definitely not broken — business, has strong financials, and has a solid story that suggests stability, maybe even some growth ahead. If there’s interest, one could check it out here.

The other one that fell within my criteria was United Parcel Service, Inc. (UPS). That’s where I’m reminded of an old Warren Buffett saying: it’s better to invest in a business you understand. It wasn’t exactly phrased like that word-for-word, but the broader meaning holds true to me. And I think, broadly and simply put, delivering packages around the world and right to the doorstep is a business most people can grasp more easily than, say, quantum computing. A 7.5% dividend yield is very attractive, and a forward-looking P/E of 13.5 made me want to dig deeper to see if I’m not missing a great opportunity here.

Having done the analysis, I rate UPS as a Buy. In my view, the current struggles are fixable, and the likelihood of a successful turnaround is relatively high. Even if finding firmer footing takes time, the dividend looks sustainable for now — unless something truly extraordinary happens.

Read more here...

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: AMLP: 4 Elements I Like To Remember About MLPs
data.description:
When I think of an income-oriented sector, with distributions uncorrelated to classic income investing instruments, I think of the MLP segment. Now, the leader in terms of AUM on the market is the Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP), and in some ways, I understand the enthusiasm. It offers high yield, it offers tax simplicity, and it has targeted exposure to the MLP segment, not to mention the macroeconomic stimuli that drive demand for stocks in this segment.

But are we sure it’s really the number one solution in this sector? Personally, I identify 4 discussion points to open.

  1. it’s too concentrated

  2. it doesn’t hold up against peers

  3. tax simplicity is not a fiscal advantage and

  4. it doesn’t have such clear positive catalysts.

Let me explain better.

What is AMLP

When we talk about AMLP, we’re talking about a leading ETF in the MLP segment, with an AUM of about $10.4B. Yet its investment strategy is very simple: it’s a passive ETF with the Alerian MLP Index (float-adjusted, cap-weighted) as its benchmark and an expense ratio of 0.85%. So the core remains U.S. energy MLPs (oil & gas pipelines), with a specific focus on the midstream energy segment (transport & storage).

1) Holding distribution: high concentration.

A first element to discuss is certainly the holding distribution. It consists of 15 100% U.S. MLPs, where the top 6 holdings cover 75% of the distribution and the top 10 weight almost 93.2%.

Can we therefore say that AMLP is quite concentrated? Yes, although it still represents well the various segments of this sector.

However, it must be said that it remains a holding distribution very easily replicable independently, even with a sampling mechanism, considering the strong concentration, but also a turnover around 20% (indicating few rebalancings), and a portfolio volatility of 14 points.

But without going into the details of sampling strategies, this is also shown simply by the linearity of AMLP with Western Midstream Partners, LP (WES), the first holding (about 12%) of AMLP.

2) Peer

Continuing in this direction, the reference peers are Global X MLP ETF (MLPA), Global X MLP & Energy Infrastructure ETF (MLPX), and the broader ENFR in terms of holdings.

It’s immediately noticeable that AMLP is the ETF with the largest AUM in circulation ($10.3B). At the same time, it’s also the most expensive, and if we look at total return, also the least profitable, both in the short and long term.

I already expressed my concerns about this in MLPA, which, although it looks at the global market, still shows a historical performance very close to AMLP (read here). And I had already stated that MLPX would in my opinion be a more competitive pick in this segment (read here). What I personally appreciate, and I recognize it may be debatable, is the presence of a structural mix that goes beyond AMLP’s concentration. In MLPX, for example, there are holdings both of midstream MLPs and energy infrastructure corporations, which is why the holding distribution broadens and total performance increases. An element that, in my opinion, is further amplified in ENFR.

Why is it so attractive?

I’ll get straight to the point, the reason why this sector is chosen, despite a capital loss of about 37% since 2010, is in my opinion the high yield element, which today is very competitive, equal to 8.3% distributed quarterly;

And it’s, in my opinion, an expression of the genuineness of the MLP segment in general (not just AMLP): not by chance there’s a good coverage ratio of the distribution, between 45% – 70%. And at the same time the sector shows good valuations: the forward EV/EBITDA is today 8.6x, which however is below the three-year average of 8.77x, with a leverage target of 2.7x – 3.2x.

Another clue is the fact that the yield has been in an upward trend for 5 years now where, very curiously, we are witnessing a certain dividend trend accelerating (3Y > 5Y). A signal of strong momentum from the midstream energy sector.

This pushes the total return into positive territory (+99% in about 15 years), which has progressively attracted more and more income investors, used to working with DRIP strategy.

And it’s a competitive yield even compared to peers. Only MLPA offers a similar structure in terms of distribution. In the others, the inclusion of parallel segments lowers the distribution.

3) The tax structure

I start with a disclaimer in my opinion very important here: the tax impact of any instrument varies depending on one’s own tax regime. So, these considerations should not be considered exhaustive: they only reflect my personal reflection and experience.

But a good chapter could be opened in this sense. This is because AMLP is not a RIC, therefore it has deferred tax liabilities theoretically positive. In this sense, the benefit of the MLPs is lost and in my personal opinion this is the reason why there is an evident divergence in performance compared to the reference index. Discussing it with other bank advisor colleagues, it seems that often the “tax simplicity” is preferred to the “convenience,” and on this I have no doubts. For this reason it is a very subjective reasoning, and I only bring you my opinion. But I repeat: personally, this leads me even more to prefer MLP stock picking.

NB: moving to the side of share distribution; it is always over 70% ROC, an element that as you know instead is associated with tax benefits (reduces the tax basis of the shares).

4) Catalysts? Which ones?

Behind the rebound of the segment there are certainly many interesting narratives. In my opinion, the prevailing one is the boom in demand coming from AI/data centers build-out. Contextualizing more based on the recent news of these weeks, there seem to be 2 other potential positive catalysts: the new U.S. sanctions against Russia but also the Fed rate cuts. This generates primarily positive pressure on the price of oil, and secondly, a potential boost for the commodities segment (because industrial expectations increase). If we add to this the pullback of about 10% since April 2025, it seems like a real opportunity.

Yet, some clarifications are needed.

Risk?

The risk of AMLP, shared also by its peers and by individual MLPs, is that they are linked to oil production. But attention, here a not insignificant disconnection is created in my opinion.

When expectations related to oil production decline, MLPs price in a potential negative cycle in their fundamentals. But this does not make AMLP an “oil price beta” ETF. And we can see the divergence in the positive tail of the return distribution.

At a fundamental level what happens? That if expectations on production fall, expectations on EBITDA fall, therefore on the coverage ratio and on the yield. And this generates a capital outflow.

The thing that for now makes me remain confident in the sector is the issue of inflation, which is often integrated into contracts (built-in inflation protection). This is why since 2022 this sector has held up well through the economic cyclical rotation. Secondly, the intentions confirmed by OPEC to increase production, not reduce it.

Conclusion

I think the MLP segment can truly help diversify the portfolio’s income sources and provide good capital preservation. On AMLP, although it is a leader in the sector, I find some weaknesses I couldn’t overlook. Considering the strong concentration, the tax burden, the presence of more competitive peers, and ultimately the lack of a clear short-term catalyst, I think the right rating for AMLP is Hold.

data.title: Vale: Another LATAM Giant With Good Prospects
data.description:
Vale S.A. (NYSE:VALE) is a producer and miner of minerals for various commercial production purposes, primarily iron ore, but also nickel and copper, due to the structure of its mines and deposits in its portfolio. Its business is primarily focused on Latin America, especially Brazil, but it also owns and manages deposits in North America and Asia. Iron ore is undoubtedly Vale's main product. It represents a total of 84 million tons of production, compared to 40,000 tons of nickel and 93,000 tons of copper.

Over the past year, the company has experienced a decline in revenue due to a fall in the international price of iron ore. This decline began rapidly in 2022 but has continued since January 2024, where it had last recovered. This trend is closely linked to the slowdown in Chinese economic growth. It is important to understand this concept because the Asian giant currently accounts for more than 50% of global steel production, the main raw material of which is iron ore.

Still, as I will try to describe in this report, especially in the following thesis segment, the characteristics of VALE as a company and the potential it has in the short and medium term.

Thesis

As previously mentioned, VALE maintains a stake in Latin America, North America, and Asia. Without a doubt, LATAM is the leading geographic region in terms of the number of tons of potentially exploitable reserves. In comparison, LATAM represents more reserves than the total estimated for Asia and North America combined.

It is true, as we mentioned, that the international price of iron ore has been steep since 2022, with the end of the pandemic and the sharp slowdown in China's growth. In this sense, the Asian giant represents one of the main demanders of this commodity, based on the fact that the country is the world's leading steel producer. Therefore, understanding China's performance in the short term is key to the future of the international price of iron ore.

Now, the question arises as to what could happen in the medium and long term. In this sense, it is necessary to understand the growth in demand that other countries and regions may experience. As can be seen below, VALE expects that, on the iron ore demand side, China will continue to show a downward trend in the medium term. However, the trend is expected to increase, driven by greater participation from India and other countries outside the main demanders at this time.

Regarding these forecasts, from my perspective, it's important to note that the expectation for India's growth is well-founded. According to some specialized websites, steel production in India is expected to grow by approximately 9% in the short term. Regarding the company's forecasts for China and its demand for iron ore, they appear to be rather conservative. Much of the market expects demand for this mineral from the Asian giant to remain strong, which could offer a better short-term outlook than the company anticipates.

Moving on to the iron ore supply, as long as international prices remain stable, VALE expects a significant portion of iron ore mines to return to profitability, leading to a recovery in production from there. However, they estimate that even then, they will not be able to cope with even more significant demand growth by 2030. These highlights price pressure that could be beneficial for the industry. This could not only lead to a recovery in the company's margins, but also, given the increase in production that VALE is expected to drive, a significant increase in revenue.

In this regard, the year 2025 represented a significant increase compared to 2024 in terms of copper and nickel tonnage. While it's true that the increase in iron ore was a smaller percentage, it grew by around 3.7% compared to 2024. Considering the volumes this metal represents in VALE's total production, we see that, from my perspective, an increase of this magnitude is interesting and attractive.

Looking ahead and toward margin recovery, it's interesting to see the company's achievements in reducing or controlling costs. While major competitors saw an increase in extraction costs per ton in 2025 compared to 2023, VALE was the exception. This year, the company reported a drop to between $20.5 and $22 per ton, and the trend is expected to continue and fall to less than $20 per ton by 2026.

To delve deeper into the topic of margins, it's interesting to see that VALE's margin percentages are well above the industry average. This positions it as one of the top players among iron ore mining companies and makes it an excellent option to take advantage of the cycle change and the supply-demand spread I mentioned earlier.

2Q2025 Results

In this segment, I would like to summarize Vale's results for the second quarter of 2025 and compare them with previous periods. First, I want to focus on production changes, and then move on to the financial results. In this regard, Vale's total iron ore production during the second quarter of 2025 was 77.35 million metric tons. This figure, compared to the 79.79 million metric tons produced in the second quarter of 2024, represents a decrease of approximately 3%. Furthermore, compared to the first quarter of 2024, production grew 17% compared to the 66.14 million metric tons produced in the first quarter.

Regarding the international price of iron ore, the downward trend mentioned in the thesis segment can be seen. As can be seen, Vale's realized price of the commodity in 2Q2025 was $97.8/ton, while in 1Q2025 it was $103.6/ton, representing a drop of approximately 6%. Compared to 2Q2024, the drop was approximately 13% compared to the $111.8/ton reported by the company.

I would now like to analyze the main financial results reported by VALE. Regarding revenues, the company reported a result of $8.8 billion in the second quarter of 2025. This represented an 11% decrease compared to the $9.9 billion for the same period in 2024. However, when we analyze it compared to the first quarter of 2025 figures, we see an 8% increase compared to the $8.12 billion for that period. This continues to reflect the trend described at the beginning of this section.

Let's now analyze the company's reported EBITDA figures. VALE reported a total of $3,386 million in 2Q2025. Again, compared to the figures reported in 2Q2024, we see a 15% drop compared to the $3,993 million reported in that period. Again, compared to 1Q2025, we see an increase of approximately 9% compared to the $3,115 million reported in that quarter. It's interesting to analyze the EV/EBITDA ratio. Annualizing the previously described figures, we can calculate a ratio of approximately 4.99x.

Another interesting point was the quarter-over-quarter decline in CapEx and compared to last year. In Q2 2025, the company's reported CapEx was $1,053 million, a 10% decrease compared to the $1,173 million reported in Q1 2025. The decline is even greater compared to Q2 2024.

Valuation

For this segment, I developed a DCF model, in order to further contribute to the description of the company and the scenario in which it operates, in light of what can be expected. In this regard, I first describe the assumptions I used to perform the calculations. Regarding the tax rate, I used 18%. While it may seem low compared to other industries, when examining the effective rate in Seeking Alpha's Financials segment, according to the data reported by the company, it can be seen that the average for recent years is below that value. I deliberately decided to perform the calculations with a higher rate to generate a margin of safety in the company's valuation.

Regarding the perpetual growth rate, I decided to use a value of 2%, which is slightly below global GDP growth in recent decades, a value to which the demand for steel, and therefore for iron ore, is closely linked. Again, the idea behind this selection was to maintain a margin of safety in relation to the company's final valuation. Regarding the WACC, I would like to explain in a little more detail why I believe a value of 10% contributes more to that margin of safety. First, when analyzing the capital structure, we can see that Vale has a market capitalization of $45.67 billion and a debt stock of $20.39 billion. This generates a debt and equity-to-total assets ratio of 30.9% and 69.1%, respectively.

Regarding the cost of debt, the volume-weighted average of bonds issued gives the company a yield of around 5.34%. In this sense, a WACC of 10% would imply a cost of equity of 12.08%, which, considering the company's beta of approximately 1.02, seems reasonable, even considering that the company's primary business is in emerging countries. In fact, when we look at specialized sites, we can see that the WACC they assign to the company is around 6.5%, considerably lower than the one I decided to choose. This is undoubtedly where I tried to be more conservative, charging a penalty precisely because of the risks inherent in the countries in which Vale operates, but also as confirmation of the generation of the safety margin I've been mentioning.

Regarding EBITDA growth, I proposed a 5% increase for the first year, 4.5% for the second, 4% for the third, 3% for the fourth, and 2.5% for the fifth, aligning with the same growth rate in perpetuity thereafter. While this may seem like a high-growth rate, as can be seen in the table below, market analysts' forecasts indicate an EPS of $1.81, while the value for 2024 was $1.42. Considering this increase, it can be seen that a 5% increase in EBITDA is quite conservative. Regarding amortization and depreciation, to simplify the calculations, I assumed they would grow at a rate equal to that of EBITDA. Finally, regarding CapEx, I estimated a constant growth of 1.5% throughout the period.

Finally, taking all these assumptions into consideration, it can be seen that the company has attractive upside potential. It's important to note that this value is obtained even under the conservative assumptions that sought to generate a margin of safety. From my perspective, these results reinforce the scenario and forecasts detailed in the thesis segment and provide further justification for the BUY rating.

Risks And Conclusion

Finally, I would like to mention the main risks that may be looming in the short term. Without a doubt, the most important to note, from my perspective, is the change in foreign trade policy undertaken by the United States government. The White House's initiative to increase import tariffs on the vast majority of countries has China as one of the main targets.

Given the impact this Asian country represents on steel production and iron ore demand, the escalation of the situation could be a major risk. While it is true that other players are expected to drive demand in the medium term, the fact that Chinese economic growth does not recover or, worse still, declines as a result of a trade war with the United States, could affect the transition period and generate a further downward trend in iron ore prices in the short term.

Still, due to the geographic location of VALE's business, I believe the Brazilian company is better positioned than some other competitors to address the risks. Given the scenario I sought and the company's valuation, I believe VALE has good growth prospects and can benefit greatly from a change in the cycle. At the same time, it has the qualities to withstand a continuation of the trend experienced by iron ore in recent years. Therefore, I consider the company a BUY.

data.title: Highlights From The Trump Administration's East Asia Deals
data.description:
In the week beginning on October 24, 2025, President Trump and his administration met with East Asian leaders. The President stopped first in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, followed by Japan and South Korea. Last, but not least, and most importantly, he met with Chinese President Xi on Thursday, Oct. 30.

What did the meeting with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (“ASEAN”) accomplish?

Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand

The White House segmented the President’s deals into three groups: peace deals, trade deals, and critical minerals deals. The peace deal might have minimal interest to readers, since defense firms like Lockheed Martin Corporation (LMT), The Boeing Company (BA), or RTX Corporation (RTX). Product sales for defense contractors are bigger in other markets and countries. For example, RTX stock jumped by 6.11% in the last month to continue its yearlong uptrend.

RTX posted resilient strength in commercial aerospace, thanks to passenger air travel resiliency. In addition, Pratt Canada serviced nearly 70,000 engines. RTX’s backlog grew by 13% Y/Y to $251 billion. Its book-to-bill in Q3 was 1.63. Collins and Pratt’s customers included NASA, General Electric Company (GE), SpaceX, and Textron Inc. (TXT).

Malaysia and Cambodia eliminated tariffs on U.S. exports. While that expands market access for U.S. products, the White House posted that “non-tariff barriers will be addressed.”

Malaysia (EWM) imported $299.5 billion in 2024. The U.S. accounted for $27.60 billion. China accounted for 24%, according to Trading Economics:

Cambodia imported $28.71 billion. Again, China was its biggest source of imports at 48%, compared to $264.17 million from the U.S.

Vietnam (VNM) Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and President Trump announced a joint statement on a U.S.-Vietnam Framework for an Agreement on Reciprocal, Fair, and Balanced Trade. The deal is incomplete. A fact sheet issued that day stated that the two countries would continue to negotiate in the coming weeks to finalize the deal.

Vietnam exports will face a 20% tariff. Any transshipment from third countries faces a 40% duty. Still, Vietnam will improve market access by resolving constraints that U.S. exports face. For example, it would recognize vehicles that meet U.S. safety and emission standards. Vietnam would simplify regulatory approvals for U.S. pharmaceutical products.

Vietnam Airlines signed a deal to buy 50 Boeing aircraft worth $8 billion.

To get an idea of Vietnam’s market size, look at the $379 billion imports in 2024. This grew by 7.2% Y/Y. China and Vietnam reached $144.3 billion worth of trade in 2024-25. The U.S. remained a key trade partner, where imports totaled $14.3 billion. It supplied Vietnam, which focused on agriculture, machinery, technology, and rubber.

Thailand agreed to eliminate tariffs on 99% of goods. Thailand (THD) will buy U.S. agricultural, energy products and aircraft. This has a value of over $20 billion.

Deal With Japan

Japan (EWJ) and the U.S. signed an agreement where the U.S. would tax goods imported from Japan at 15%. Japan agreed to create a $550 billion fund of investments in the U.S. Japanese firms expressed interest in launching projects in the U.S. worth around $400 billion in total. They want to invest in energy, which AI infrastructure requires to run. Still, the Japan Times reported that the deal did not finalize any of the projects.

Honda Motor Co., Ltd. (HMC), Toyota Motor Corporation (TM), and Sony Group Corporation (SONY) are among the biggest firms to watch. Tariffs have an impact on their export volumes.

Above: Sony is the first in its industry rank, while Toyota scores a B or higher in all of its quant factor grades.

China Deal

The U.S. did not sign a trade deal when the two leaders met for less than two hours (as reported by CNN). This was a face-to-face talk in Busan, South Korea (EWY), which was their first meeting since 2019. Trump agreed to lower tariffs on Chinese exports to 47%, down from 57%. The U.S. will cut the tariff rates related to fentanyl precursor drugs by half, to 10%.

China agreed to pause (delay for one year), not cancel, export controls on rare earths. Similarly, Treasury Secretary Bessent confirmed that the U.S. would pause its new expansion of export controls. This freezes the 50% BIS (Bureau of Industry and Security) rule. The rule would have extended last year’s announced export-licensing requirements. That would have applied to firms that were majority-owned by parties on the entity list, military end-user list, or part of the specially designated nationals.

China agreed to buy 12 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans until January 2026. It will buy 25 million tons a year for the next three years. China bought 28.8 million tons on average in the last five September-to-August crop seasons. Soybean (SOYB) prices have jumped since October 10. SOYB stock is up by around 6.5% in the last month.

Bessent said that China approved the transfer agreement for TikTok. A Chinese spokesperson said, “The Chinese side will work with the U.S. side to properly address issues related to TikTok." Ahead of the news, Oracle Corporation (ORCL), considered a frontrunner in acquiring the short-form video site, underperformed. ORCL stock potentially peaked at around $340. The stock has spiked at lower highs since September and is down by 7.68% in the last week.

Trump said on Truth Social that China would buy U.S. oil and gas. Additionally, he announced a “very large-scale transaction (that) may take place” involving Alaska. Some liquefied natural gas stocks to explore further include Cheniere Energy, Inc. (LNG), Kinder Morgan, Inc. (KMI), and Energy Transfer LP (ET). ConocoPhillips (COP) is Alaska’s biggest oil producer. Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) has a stake in the Prudhoe Bay oil field, but Hilcorp replaced it as the operator in 2021.

Above: XOM stock has the highest sector rank. It has a 'Strong Buy' on Seeking Alpha's Quant Ratings.

Potential Economic Impact

Readers who craved for firm trade deals might be disappointed. The U.S. and China paused tariffs and restrictions, respectively, for one year. They will continue to play their long game using short-term agreements in principle. Investors will need to exercise caution in holding companies that struggled before tariffs. For example, Newell Brands Inc. (NWL) lost 32% despite indicating the impact of tariffs subsiding in 2026.

China is not faring well economically. Weaker exports, hurt by U.S. tariffs, resulted in factory activity falling to a six-month low. China’s (FXI) NBS Manufacturing PMI fell to 49.0%. Investors would not likely notice the weak data. FXI stock is up by 25% in the last year. The country’s technology stocks are up, too. Alibaba Group Holding Limited (BABA) gained 98.8% and Tencent Holdings Limited (OTCPK:TCEHY) is up by 51.8% YTD. Technology investors need not worry about the absence of discussing NVIDIA Corporation's (NVDA) Blackwell chip sales to China. The AI race to the top will continue between the U.S. and China.

Above: In the five-day period, shares of Tencent, Baidu, Inc. (BIDU), Alibaba, and JD.com, Inc. (JD) pulled back. Below: BIDU and JD shares offer compelling value.

Your Takeaway

Stock markets trade near their all-time highs. In the last week, earnings reports from the Magnificent Seven, along with the Federal Reserve’s 25 bps rate cut, influenced markets heavily. In the coming weeks, the U.S. will get a better idea of the impact of the deals with ASEAN nations, especially with China.

data.title: Lowe's: Price May Follow Earnings And Recover With Consumers, But Upside Could Be Capped
data.description:
Lowe's Companies, Inc. (NYSE:LOW) is an American retail company, specializing in home improvement, maintenance, and decorating products and services. This is one of a few market-leading companies with a significant presence, highlighting more than 1,700 stores.

LOW stock has declined by 9% over the past 12 months, mainly driven by weak US consumer demand due to an elevated interest-rate environment and slower demand for home improvements. I think a meaningful decrease in new home sales trends, experienced since about 2021, has also significantly contributed to its bearish performance. Although the chart below highlights that new home sales may resume, it may take time for this to translate into significant top and bottom-line growth.

This is why I think that Lowe's Companies is a Hold with a $266 price target over the next 12 months. This suggests roughly market-like returns, highlighting a 9% upside possibility without dividends. I believe the stock price may mirror bottom-line growth.

However, unless consumers significantly recover and real estate activity increases, I am not sure whether the company can substantially outperform the benchmark in the following year. It has several tailwinds tied to a dovish Fed and easing cycle, but policy might take time; therefore, I remain cautious and monitor the macroeconomic outlook.

FQ2 2026 Snapshot: Double-Beat Performance, Guiding For A Positive Shift

On August 20, the company delivered FQ2 2026 results. This was a double-beat quarter, implying a shift in resumed top-line growth and bottom-line increase. However, based on the neutral investors' reaction, it seems that the market had already anticipated a turnaround, as the stock remained flat with roughly a 0.60% drop over the following trading day.

Lowe's posted $23.96 billion in revenue, up by 1.58% on a year-over-year basis, breaking the streak of 9 consecutive top-line decline quarters. This arrived at about $9 million above what the market had anticipated. The bottom line came in at $4.33 in diluted EPS, indicating approximately 6% increase versus $4.10 in the same quarter last year, and $0.09 above the analysts' estimates, implying a 2% surprise.

Management highlighted that the comparable sales increased by 1.1%, which is uplifting, considering the company has been experiencing a multi-month top-line contraction. The retail company underscored that it achieved 33.8% gross margin and 14.5% operating margin.

The home renovation business represented a 3.6% increase in comparable sales for ticket sizes exceeding $500, which I believe is promising and supports a bullish future. This also correlates to an increase in new home sales in the US, implying that home renovation products are typically tied to a higher price tag. Moreover, it may indicate that consumer spending is improving, and that would be a positive tailwind for this retail industry.

On the upside, the company highlighted it has experienced positive comparable sales in 9 out of 15 regions it operates. This also supports a bullish narrative and may sustain a positive stock price momentum, underlining a roughly 7% increase over the past 6 months. I think this quarterly report underscored a promising shift in the company's performance. If the trend continues, I believe Lowe may rebound from these levels.

Lowe's is expected to deliver its FQ3 2026 results on November 19, before the market opens. The market is forecasting $20.88 billion in revenue, implying about a 3.5% growth on a year-over-year basis, and roughly $3.00 in diluted EPS, representing approximately a 3.7% increase over the past 12 months. I think the company appears to be well-positioned to achieve these results. Given its recent performance and uptick in new home sales, LOW may meet the market expectations. If that materializes, investor confidence may improve, followed by expectations of a recovering consumer.

Lowe's Appears To Be Fairly Priced, And I Argue That The Market Has Priced In The Consumer Recovery

The home renovation retailer currently trades at a forward P/E of about 20, which appears to be approximately 12% overvalued versus the sector median of around 18 earnings multiples. However, versus the average company in the S&P500 at roughly 24x, Lowe's trades at a 20% discount.

The chart above also suggests that the current valuation reflects the high end of the trading range, which supports my outlook that upside may be limited in the near term. The forward P/E has increased significantly from about the mid-14's back in December 2023 to the current levels, mainly driven by the bottoming phase in the real estate market, as that period reflected the weakest activity over the past years. This also may support my stance that consumer recovery may already be priced in.

On the forward PEG (non-GAAP) basis of 3.16, the company appears to be trading at a substantial premium to peers at 1.73. This implies more than an 80% premium, which adds an extra argument to my bearish stance. This also clouds a positive outlook.

The forward EV/Sales and Price/Sales ratios of 2.01 and 1.61, respectively, justify my thesis supporting a slightly bearish outlook, and that the market may have already priced in the improvement of consumer spending. This presents 60% overvaluation at the midpoint versus the sector median of 1.35 and 0.97. This also shows that even though the home renovation company may post an acceleration in top-line growth, this does not necessarily result in stock price appreciation.

Lowe's remains a heavily leveraged company, and that may cap the upside in the near term. The retail name has $39 billion in total obligations, which appears to be significant, and resulted in $355 million in interest expenses to service the debt. Although it has $5.26 billion in cash that partially offsets its obligations, it remains elevated and could weigh on the stock price further.

The company had achieved a roughly flat performance on both top and bottom lines over the past year. LOW experienced a 0.49% revenue decline and 0.93% EPS growth over the past 12 months. This may suggest that the current valuation appears slightly too high. However, I think investors have priced in the consumer recovery, which resulted in a premium multiple. Nevertheless, this suggests that if the company experiences weaker-than-anticipated results, the stock price could correct from these levels.

The retail company has been operating at a roughly market-like gross profit margin (TTM) of about 34%, which justifies a fair valuation. This implies about a 13% discount to peers in the consumer discretionary segment, but I think that with consumer recovery, the company may be able to enhance profitability metrics. However, this is an area to monitor for investors, as higher margins could result in premium multiples.

On the other hand, the net income margin (TTM) of 8.20% reflects about 2x outperformance versus peers of 4.31%, and that supports a bullish narrative for the company. This also highlights that LOW remains a highly profitable business, which may fuel the bottom-line growth in the following years. This also supports my thesis that the stock price may follow EPS expansion.

Wall Street estimates a $12.32 in diluted EPS for fiscal FY2026, up by 3% on a year-over-year basis, and $13.32 for fiscal FY2027, reflecting 8% increase versus the fiscal FY2026 estimate. I think Lowe's appears to be well-positioned to achieve these results. The company remains profitable, operating at market-like margins. If real estate activity continues to improve, and consumer spending rises, this may act as a substantial tailwind driving the bottom-line growth.

If we apply a roughly current earnings multiple of 20x to a fiscal FY2027 EPS estimate of $13.32, we arrive at my price target of $266. This would represent about 9% upside possibility, driven by bottom-line growth. However, given the macroeconomic uncertainties, I think the stock may mirror its EPS performance, yet I am not sure whether LOW can significantly outperform the benchmark without a significant revenue growth catalyst.

Main Risks And Concerns

There are risks and concerns tied to Lowe's that could meaningfully impact the stock price performance in the short term.

The home renovation company is highly dependent on the macroeconomic outlook. If inflation remains elevated or the job market weakens, this could result in slower-than-anticipated consumer spending and suppressed sentiment. This may also encourage the Fed to pause the easing cycle, which would establish an unfavorable environment for the company. This could stress its performance and result in continued underperformance.

Although new home sales experienced an uptick, and their growth appears to be resuming, it may not necessarily be the case. There is a possibility that, followed by macroeconomic uncertainties, new home sales may come in weaker-than-anticipated. This could pressure the stock price further.

Lowe's is exposed to tariffs, and that is a concern. This is another argument for suppressed margins, and if tariffs will remain a concern over the following years, the market may reprice the company at a lower multiple. Because of this, the company is also experiencing cost inflation, which supports my limited upside narrative.

Considering its 12-month top and bottom-line performance, LOW experiences stagnation. However, it also trades at only a 20% discount to the benchmark. This suggests that if the outlook remains cloudy, investors may not be willing to pay a higher premium for the company.

On the upside, if none of the above materializes, and tariff risks and concerns fade away, the company could continue trading at a premium, and there may even be room for multiple expansion. I believe that investors should monitor whether an uptick in new home sales was only a short-term blip. If that is not the case, LOW may be able to accelerate its top and bottom-line expansion, which may be bullish for its stock.

Conclusion: Macro Shifts Appear Promising, But I Remain Cautious — A Hold

I think that Lowe's may appear to be an interesting opportunity for long-term investors who may seek to diversify into the retail industry with exposure to real estate markets. For multiple years now, the real estate landscape has been stressed, but recent progress highlighting an uptick in new home sales may be promising and supports a bullish stance for the company.

Nevertheless, it remains trading at elevated multiples, despite experiencing stagnation on both the top and bottom line. This highlights that the market may already be priced in for future growth, which would suggest upside may be limited in the near term. To that, there is a risk that improved consumer spending in real estate was just a one-off blip, which may suggest that investors could reprice the stock at a lower multiple if tailwinds do not materialize.

Given this, and a fairly valued stock, I think Lowe's Companies is a Hold. I think the stock may mirror bottom-line expansion, but I also don't believe it could significantly outperform the benchmark without a meaningful revenue growth catalyst. I forecast a $266 price target over the next 12 months, suggesting a 9% upside potential, but unlikely to outperform the broader market. 35 Wall Street analysts forecast a $282 price target, implying a roughly 18% upside possibility. This is a possibility, but I remain cautious until more data regarding real estate market activity appears.

data.title: Why Growth Investors Are Eyeing Broadcom As AI Market Expands
data.description:
I last wrote about Broadcom (NASDAQ: AVGO) on Sept. 11 when I upgraded it from a hold to a buy, despite its high valuation. The market has been reluctant to push the stock much higher recently, likely because some consider it overvalued. The stock has essentially flatlined since my last article on Broadcom. However, there are still reasons growth investors may want to purchase this stock despite trading at what some consider an elevated valuation.

The most significant reason investors may want to invest in Broadcom today is the potential for massive revenue growth acceleration from its artificial intelligence ("AI") business. Recently, Chief Executive Officer Hock Tan tied his pay incentives to the company's AI business, with the condition that the AI business achieve certain revenue in 2030. At the Goldman Sachs Communacopia + Technology Conference 2025 on Sept. 9, CEO Tan said:

As you know, I signed up for an extension of my contract to 2030. With this extension, of course, I get some incentives. One of that incentives that tied to it is tied to - so you guys know AI revenue for Broadcom, very simple. And I need to hit to achieve max on my incentive for 2030, five years from now, give you a sense, AI revenue of exceeding $120 billion, OK? Today, '25, our AI revenue is $20 billion. But that gives you a sense of our belief how strong the demand for compute is in this race towards AI, generative AI, super intelligence.

Suppose you plug those numbers ($20 billion in 2025 and $120 billion in 2030) into a compound annual growth rate ("CAGR") calculator. In that case, it results in a 43.1% CAGR over five years—absolutely explosive revenue growth from AI alone. Hock Tan has been the CEO of Broadcom since March 2006, following Avago Technologies' merger with Broadcom and the formation of the new Broadcom Inc. The company has displayed excellent execution during Hock Tan's reign. A bet that Hock Tan can guide Broadcom to $120 billion in AI revenue by 2030 is not a bad bet. It's within the realm of possibility, especially considering the growth of the AI marketplace.

He also noted at the conference that the company initially projected 60% revenue growth for fiscal year ("FY") 2026, but now expects that growth rate to accelerate beyond 60%. Typically, when revenue growth accelerates, momentum investors bid up the stock price. Broadcom's report date for fourth quarter 2025 earnings is on Dec. 11. If the company beats analysts' revenue estimates and raises 2026 guidance when it reports fourth-quarter earnings, it may spark a post-earnings rally in the stock—a good reason to invest in the near term.

AI Compute and networking

During the Goldman Sachs Communacopia + Technology Conference 2025, CEO Hock Tan explained he views the AI market in two distinct customer groups. The first group (the creators) consists of only a few significant players that include hyperscalers such as Alphabet (GOOGL)(GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and "super start-ups" or labs (like OpenAI, Anthropic) that are creating the Large Language Models (LLMs) and new platforms of the future. Hock Tan estimates that several players in the creator market spend up to $30 billion a year on AI infrastructure.

Hock Tan describes the creator group at the Goldman Sachs Conference:

These are the guys who are really making that investment in LLMs, which entail huge amount of R&D, particularly in respect to training, which is just - not just creating that algorithms to create those LLMs and make it work, but to also create the ability and spend on the ability to train huge amounts of data to improve on their journey towards super intelligence as we - for (want) of a better word.

The second group is a more fragmented group of AI users, or the enterprise market, consisting of thousands of regular companies, public cloud customers, and government/sovereign entities, who are primarily interested in using AI to improve their businesses and achieve "productivity gains." These users are rarely interested in doing much training. The AI user market is essentially the AI inference market. Hock Tan estimates the AI user market consists of around 10,000 customers today, each spending around $10 million a year, for a total of $100 billion.

CEO Tan also discussed the AI user market at the Goldman conference:

There's thousands and thousands of companies out there who are looking at AI as a very interesting tool to improve the way they run their business to basically achieve mostly productivity gains, which is truly - and trying to find use case for it and doubling most of them POCs (proof of concepts) right now on AI tools and trying to run AI and whether they get that ability through renting GPUs or buying some and running on-prem, these are that category. And that category of market are largely inference, truly inference. They talk about training. It's limited. Post training, perhaps, test time scaling, but it's all inference. It's looking for use case and trying to get a return on investment, mostly on productivity. And these guys are going to stay largely on merchant silicon, merchant GPU because they're not going to create XPUs, write software stacks to make it work and figure out all these things.

The creator group may have fewer potential customers, but it's still a sizeable market. Broadcom has little interest in marketing to the AI users market or enterprise customers who are primarily interested in using graphics processing units ("GPUs") manufactured by Nvidia (NVDA) or Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), rather than Broadcom's customized XPUs.

Although the AI chip gets all the hype, Broadcom's biggest advantage in AI infrastructure is its networking products. Not many companies have the resources to compete with Broadcom's networking knowledge, SerDes (Serializer/Deserializer) IP, and deep expertise. SerDes is the technology that moves data between chips at extremely high speeds. Broadcom has pioneered the development and integration of this high-speed IP into its ASICs, making it a key differentiating factor for building large AI clusters (XPUs/custom AI chips). Although many companies have entered the ASIC space over the years, competitors have had difficulty beating Broadcom in the AI infrastructure category because replicating its networking and connectivity technology is difficult.

The LLM Creator market is the only segment that truly pushes the limits of networking, a core Broadcom strength. CEO Hock Tan discussed the importance of networking at the Goldman Conference:

You are not able to do this generative AI training of this huge database to create this billion, billion parameters models with one single GPU or XPU, no matter how hard you try. You need to create a cluster of them. And the more complex your LLM becomes, the larger your clusters have to be. Then you face yourself a totally different problem. How do you create all this matrix multiplication across, say, 100,000 of the GPU simultaneously. And then you go to 1 million. That's even a bigger headache. That's one of the - that is, in fact, I consider the biggest technology challenge in computing on generative AI as you progress your models higher. And that comes in the other aspect, networking. How do you connect them? How do you have the bandwidth to connect them? How do you schedule the workloads, orchestrate it so that they can all run in parallel. This is more so as much software as the networking side, which is hardware. I think this is one of the biggest challenge towards progression, making massive progress on being able to create super intelligence. How do you get these huge workloads that you're supposed to run on these huge models and be able to train a huge amount of data on a 1 million GPU or XPU simultaneously and converge on a solution.

In other words, AMD and Nvidia, or one of the new players like Groq, Tenstorrent, Lightmatter, Mythic, Hailo, and SambaNova, could build the greatest individual AI chip in the world, and it would all be for naught if they're not networked together optimally. Since networking is Broadcom's bread and butter, with its IP in SerDes and high-performance Ethernet switches like Tomahawk and Jericho, it has a significant advantage over most companies. The only company that I can think of off the top of my head that has the networking chops to compete with Broadcom is Marvell (MRVL). So, despite press releases from some of its competitors about creating the latest and greatest super-duper chip, some will never be able to overcome Broadcom's networking moat. Customers who buy its hardware, networking, and software understand Broadcom's advantages, and it's unlikely these companies will switch to competitors easily in the near future.

Valuation

Broadcom's price-to-sales (P/S) ratio is 29.34, well above its three-, five-, seven-, and 10-year medians. Either the market overvalues the stock or expects revenue to increase rapidly or for its revenue to become more valuable (increasing margins).

If the stock begins trading at its three-year median today, its stock price would be $185.34, a 50% decline from its Oct. 28 market close of $372.97.

The following table compares Broadcom with its peers using its FY 2026 P/S to revenue growth (P/S/G) and trailing 12-month ("TTM") profitability metrics. Typically, in this comparison, the market considers the company with the highest P/S/G ratio as overvalued compared to those with the lowest P/S/G ratio.

Company Name 2026 Forward P/S ratio 2026 Forward estimated revenue growth 2026 Forward P/S ratio-to-estimated revenue growth TTM free cash flow ("FCF") margin TTM Gross Margin TTM Operating Margin TTM ROIC
Broadcom 20.06 34.57% 0.58 41.60% 63.13% 39.33% 13.77%
Advanced Micro Devices 10.01 27.27% 0.37 13.65% 43.20% 8.36% 4.49%
NVIDIA 22.51 58.43% 0.38 43.59% 69.85% 58.09% 98.69%
Marvell 9.38 40.98% 0.23 21.15% 44.64% 6.02% -0.57%
Qualcomm (QCOM) 4.37 2.06% 2.11 26.86% 55.68% 28.09% 27.99%
Intel (INTC) 3.68 2.31% 1.59 -15.75 35.77% 0.03% 0.13%
ARM Holdings (ARM) 38.70 18.22% 2.12 15.94% 94.18% 18.35% 10.44%

Since companies with relatively lower revenue growth rates can skew the comparison, I'm excluding Qualcomm, ARM, and Intel from this comparison.

Among the relatively high-growth companies—Nvidia, Marvell, Broadcom, and AMD—Broadcom has the highest P/S/G, suggesting the market may overvalue it relative to its peers.

Since Broadcom lags only Nvidia in FCF margin, gross margin, and operating margin, and has a solid ROIC, the market likely considers its premium P/S/G justified. The market would likely consider Broadcom fairly valued to slightly undervalued in this comparison.

The following chart shows analysts' estimates that Broadcom's EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization) will grow from $41.85 billion in FY 2025 at a 30.35% CAGR to $71.16 billion in FY 2027.

The following table compares AMD's forward enterprise value to EBITDA, its two-year EBITDA CAGR, and its TTM EBITDA margin with those of its peers.

Company name Forward EV/EBITDA Two-year EBITDA CAGR TTM EBITDA margin Forward EV/EBITDA to two-year EBITDA growth
ARM Holdings 81.27 32.92% 23.20% 2.47
AMD 62.10 56.57% 18.74% 1.10
Broadcom 43.37 30.35% 54.61% 1.43
NVIDIA 38.07 30.13% 59.49% 1.26
Marvell 25.15 14.92% 24.33% 1.68
Intel 17.36 27.47% 21.22% 0.63
Qualcomm 12.03 0.64% 31.95% 18.79

I'm removing ARM from consideration in this comparison because it has the highest EV/EBITDA, but it doesn't have the highest EBITDA growth rates or margins. It's an anomaly in this comparison because it doesn't manufacture chips and only licenses the intellectual property, which distorts the EV/EBITDA comparison because it has lower operating costs than companies with manufacturing operations.

Generally, in this comparison, the market considers the company with the highest EV/EBITDA ratio to be overvalued compared to those with lower ratios. After excluding ARM, the market ranks AMD as the most overvalued, followed by Broadcom.

If we divide the EV/EBITDA by the EBITDA growth rate, the resulting figure tells us how much an investor is willing to pay for every dollar of a company's EBITDA growth. I will also exclude Qualcomm from the comparison because of its extremely low growth rate, which would make it another outlier.

After excluding ARM and Qualcomm, Marvell has the highest EV/EBITDA-to-growth, followed by Broadcom. The market would likely consider Broadcom overvalued compared to all companies in the comparison except Marvell.

The company's TTM price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is 95.81, well above the information technology sector median of 31.72, which the market would consider either a sign of overvaluation or that earnings will grow much faster in the future.

Broadcom's FY 2025 forward P/E to estimated earnings-per-share ("EPS") growth ("PEG") ratio is 1.43, calculated by dividing its FY 2025 forward P/E of 55.27 by analysts' estimated EPS growth of 38.56%. Since the stock has a PEG ratio between 1.0 and 2.0, growth investors may consider it fairly valued. Generally, growth investors will allow a stock's PEG to go above 2.0 before considering it overvalued. Suppose the stock traded at a PEG ratio of 2.0 today; the stock price would be $520.56, representing a 39.57% rise from its Oct. 28 price of $372.97.

If it sold at an FY 2026 PEG ratio of 2.0, its stock price would be $699.35, an 87.50% rise over its Oct. 28 closing price.

Its price-to-FCF ratio is 73.46, well above its three-, five-, seven-, and 10-year medians. Some investors may consider the stock overvalued. If it traded at its three-year median today, its stock price would be $162.72, a 56.37% decline from its Oct. 28 closing price.

The following reverse discounted cash flow uses a terminal growth rate of 3%, reflecting what I believe will be the U.S. market's long-term inflation rate. This reverse DCF uses a discount rate of 9%, which I base on AMD's weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 9.11%, reflecting an average or moderate risk level.

This reverse DCF analysis utilizes the following TTM FCF data from YCharts.

Reverse DCF

The fourth quarter of fiscal year (FY) 2025 reported TTM FCF

 $24,930
Terminal growth rate 3%
Discount Rate 9%
Years 1-10 growth rate 21.7%
Stock Price (October 28, 2025, closing price) $372.97
Terminal FCF value $187.568 billion
Discounted Terminal Value $1,320.510 billion
TTM FCF margin 41.60%

According to this reverse DCF, Broadcom needs to grow its FCF 21.7% annually over the next 10 years to justify its Oct. 28 closing price. The company would have a strong head start, as analysts forecast FCF growth of 49.56% in 2025, 44.68% in 2026, and 36.42% in 2027. Whether the company can sustain that growth beyond 2027 depends on whether it continues to benefit from AI industry growth, which is not guaranteed.

However, momentum investors likely don't care about the growth rate that the company can sustain over the next ten years. Momentum investors are looking at the FCF growth rates they believe the company can achieve in 2026 and 2027 to gauge whether to invest.

Risks
